front.question: Most prehospital cardiac arrests in adults occur as the result of:
If gastric distention begins to make positive-pressure ventilation difficult, you should:
front.source: See Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation

front.question: What is the correct ratio of compressions to ventilations when performing two-rescuer child CPR?

choices: if you ventilate a patient too quickly.
when the airway is completely obstructed.
when you deliver minimal tidal volume.
front.question: Gastric distention will MOST likely occur:
front.source: See Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation

cards.back: if you ventilate a patient too quickly.

front.question: CPR retraining is the MOST effective when it:
front.source: See Education and Training for the EMT

front.question: When assessing the pulse of an unresponsive infant, you should palpate the ________ artery.
CPR will NOT be effective if the patient is:
Which of the following maneuvers should be used to open a patient’s airway when a spinal injury is suspected?
front.source: See Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation

choices: determine if he has a valid living will.
withhold CPR until he is defibrillated.
begin CPR until an AED is available.
front.question: A 60-year-old man is found to be unresponsive, pulseless, and apneic. You should:

cards.back: begin CPR until an AED is available.

choices: no greater than 100 compressions per minute.
front.question: To ensure that you will deliver the appropriate number of chest compressions during one-rescuer adult CPR, you should compress the patient’s chest at a rate of:
Initial treatment to dislodge a severe foreign body airway obstruction in a responsive infant involves:
front.source: See Foreign Body Airway Obstruction in Infants and Children

front.question: When performing chest compressions on an adult, the EMT should compress:

choices: has a pulse but is unresponsive and breathing shallowly.
has experienced trauma but is breathing effectively.
is semiconscious, injured, and breathing adequately.
is unresponsive, uninjured, and breathing adequately.
front.question: A patient should be placed in the recovery position when he or she:
front.source: See Opening the Airway and Providing Artificial Ventilation

cards.back: is unresponsive, uninjured, and breathing adequately.

front.question: What is the minimum number of chest compressions that should be delivered per minute to a 4-month-old infant?
Complications associated with chest compressions include all of the following, EXCEPT:
front.source: See Check for Breathing and a Pulse

front.question: In two-rescuer adult CPR, you should deliver a compression to ventilation ratio of:

choices: until a radial pulse is felt.
to a depth of 1 to 2 inches.
